Course.Title: WORLD LITERATURE
Course.Description: Readings in world literature from ancient times to present.  Emphasis on cultural diversity, selected themes, and literary genres.  Development of aesthetic and ethical values and critical reading, thinking, and writing.

Sections.CourseDescription: Readings in world literature from ancient times to present.  Emphasis on cultural diversity, selected themes, and literary genres.  Development of aesthetic and ethical values and critical reading, thinking, and writing.
MeetingsDisplay: Monday, Thursday 5:30 PM - 6:45 PM WKU General Education Hall A207 (Lecture)
Sections.Title: WORLD LITERATURE

Course.Title: RESEARCH IN LANGUAGE AND LIT.
Course.Description: Acquaints students with analysis of language and reinforces critical approaches to literature. Extends and solidifies students' writing practices and editing strategies for language and literature studies. Teaches library and field research methods to prepare students to write papers in upper level courses. Writing Emphasis. Research Emphasis.

Sections.CourseDescription: Acquaints students with analysis of language and reinforces critical approaches to literature. Extends and solidifies students' writing practices and editing strategies for language and literature studies. Teaches library and field research methods to prepare students to write papers in upper level courses. Writing Emphasis. Research Emphasis.
MeetingsDisplay: Tuesday, Friday 1:00 PM - 2:15 PM WKU General Education Hall C406 (Lecture)
Sections.Title: RESEARCH IN LANG. & LIT.

Course.Title: WRITING FOR DIGITAL SPACES
Course.Description: This course explores emerging theories and practices within the digital humanities and surveys the relationship between electronic writing products and their relationship with new media. Writing Emphasis.

Sections.CourseDescription: This course explores emerging theories and practices within the digital humanities and surveys the relationship between electronic writing products and their relationship with new media. Writing Emphasis.
MeetingsDisplay: Monday, Thursday 8:30 AM - 9:45 AM WKU General Education Hall B506 (Lecture)

Course.Title: BUSINESS&PROFESSIONAL WRITING
Course.Description: Readings, discussion, and writing projects focused on writing for the workplace, including completion of a resume and a formal report. Emphasis placed on rhetorical conventions, style, design, and formatting. Writing Emphasis.

Course.Title: TECHNICAL WRITING
Course.Description: Examination of and practice in creating supporting documents used in science and technical fields, including correspondence, descriptions, resumes, definitions, instructions, and reports.  Emphasis on writing in response to specific contexts and ensuring content is understandable and user friendly. Writing Emphasis

Sections.CourseDescription: Examination of and practice in creating supporting documents used in science and technical fields, including correspondence, descriptions, resumes, definitions, instructions, and reports.  Emphasis on writing in response to specific contexts and ensuring content is understandable and user friendly. Writing Emphasis
MeetingsDisplay: Monday, Thursday 10:00 AM - 11:15 AM WKU General Education Hall B506 (Lecture)
Sections.Title: TECHNICAL WRITING

Course.Title: SHAKESPEARE SURVEY
Course.Description: Introduction to Shakespeare's comedies, histories, tragedies, and romances.  Formerly:  ENG 2215.

MeetingsDisplay: Monday, Thursday 11:30 AM - 12:45 PM WKU General Education Hall B507 (Lecture)
Sections.Title: SHAKESPEARE SURVEY

Course.Title: YOUNG ADULT LITERATURE
Course.Description: The examination of modern literature for or about young adults as a viable literary genre with its own characteristics, history, and body of criticism.  Emphasis on selections of literature for adolescents at various stages and analysis of issues in the field, such as censorship, new media, and the canon.

Sections.CourseDescription: The examination of modern literature for or about young adults as a viable literary genre with its own characteristics, history, and body of criticism.  Emphasis on selections of literature for adolescents at various stages and analysis of issues in the field, such as censorship, new media, and the canon.
MeetingsDisplay: Tuesday, Friday 5:30 PM - 6:45 PM WKU General Education Hall B201 (Lecture)
Sections.Title: YOUNG ADULT LITERATURE

Course.Title: BRITISH ROMANTIC LITERATURE
Course.Description: Writings of representative British Romantic authors studied in relation to one another and to the history and culture of their period.

Sections.CourseDescription: Writings of representative British Romantic authors studied in relation to one another and to the history and culture of their period.
MeetingsDisplay: Monday, Thursday 10:00 AM - 11:15 AM WKU General Education Hall C305 (Lecture)
Sections.Title: BRIT ROMANTIC LIT

Course.Title: WRITING FOR SOCIAL CHANGE
Course.Description: This writing course explores nonfiction, fiction , poetry, and multimodal work that engages with social justice. Additionally, the course supports writing and critical thinkg processes such as brainstorming, researching, editing, revising, and publishing their work. Class may be taken more than once for credit if topics differ.

Sections.CourseDescription: This writing course explores nonfiction, fiction , poetry, and multimodal work that engages with social justice. Additionally, the course supports writing and critical thinkg processes such as brainstorming, researching, editing, revising, and publishing their work. Class may be taken more than once for credit if topics differ.
MeetingsDisplay: Tuesday, Friday 10:00 AM - 11:15 AM WKU General Education Hall B505 (Lecture)
Sections.Title: WRITING FOR SOCIAL CHANGE

Course.Title: INDEP STUDY FOR ENGLISH MAJORS
Course.Description: Opportunity for English majors of advanced ability to pursue in a concentrated manner a specific area of study in literature, language, or writing not available through current course offerings. Approximately forty-five hours of supervised work required for each credit hour. Only six credits may be applied toward the 124 credits for graduation.

Sections.CourseDescription: Opportunity for English majors of advanced ability to pursue in a concentrated manner a specific area of study in literature, language, or writing not available through current course offerings. Approximately forty-five hours of supervised work required for each credit hour. Only six credits may be applied toward the 124 credits for graduation.
MeetingsDisplay: Monday, Thursday 5:30 PM - 6:45 PM TBD (Lecture)
Sections.FullTitleDisplay: ENG*4812*IND01 INDEP STUDY FOR ENGLISH MAJORS
Sections.Title: INDEP STUDY FOR ENGLISH MAJORS

Course.Title: SENIOR WRITING SEMINAR
Course.Description: Writing a substantial original manuscript in a genre of the student's choice and a reflective critical essay on its creation; study of models and theories of authorship.  Required for students majoring in the writing option. Writing Emphasis.

Sections.CourseDescription: Writing a substantial original manuscript in a genre of the student's choice and a reflective critical essay on its creation; study of models and theories of authorship.  Required for students majoring in the writing option. Writing Emphasis.
MeetingsDisplay: Tuesday, Friday 8:30 AM - 9:45 AM WKU General Education Hall B507 (Lecture)
Sections.Comments: WENZHOU-KEAN STUDENTS ONLY. Senior English Majors Only
Sections.Title: SENIOR WRITING SEMINAR
